entry.et: Middle English boun, from Old Norse būinn, past participle of būa to dwell, prepare; akin to Old High German būan to dwell bower

def.dt: :ready
:intending to go :going bound for home college-bound

entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French bounde, bodne, from Medieval Latin bodina

def.dt: :a limiting line :boundary usually used in plural
:something that limits or restrains beyond the bounds of decency
:borderland
:the land within certain bounds
:a number greater than or equal to every number in a set (as the range of a function)
:a number less than or equal to every number in a set
:to set limits or bounds to :confine
:to form the boundary of :enclose
:to name the boundaries of

entry.et: Middle English bounden, from past participle of binden to bind

def.dt: :placed under legal or moral restraint or obligation :obliged duty-bound
:fastened by or as if by a band :confined desk-bound
:very likely :sure bound to rain soon
:made costive :constipated
:secured to the covers by cords, tapes, or glue
:determined resolved
:held in chemical or physical combination
:always occurring in combination with another linguistic form un- in unknown and -er in speaker are bound forms compare free 11d

entry.et: Middle French bond, from bondir to leap, from Vulgar Latin *bombitire to hum, from Latin bombus deep hollow sound bomb

def.dt: :leap jump
:the action of rebounding :bounce
:to move by leaping
:rebound bounce

entry.et: Middle English, from Old English bindan; akin to Old High German bintan to bind, Greek peisma cable, Sanskrit badhnāti he ties

def.dt: :to make secure by tying
:to confine, restrain, or restrict as if with bonds
:to put under an obligation binds himself with an oath
:to constrain with legal authority
:to wrap around with something so as to enclose or cover
:bandage
:to fasten round about
:to tie together (as stocks of wheat)
:to cause to stick together
:to take up and hold (as by chemical forces) :combine with
:constipate
:to make a firm commitment for a handshake binds the deal
:to protect, strengthen, or decorate by a band or binding
:to apply the parts of the cover to (a book)
:to set at work as an apprentice :indenture
:to cause to have an emotional attachment
:to fasten together a pin bound the ends of the scarf
:to form a cohesive mass
:to combine or be taken up especially by chemical action antibody binds to a specific antigen
:to hamper free movement or natural action
:to become hindered from free operation
:to exert a restraining or compelling effect a promise that binds
:closely involved or associated usually used with with his life was bound up with the town's history
:bound in material of two qualities with the material of better quality on the spine and corners
